sentences.original: kayâs pêyak okimâw, nîsoh okimâwak, oskinîkiwak, pêyak owîkimâkanah miyosiyiwa; wiya mîna miyosiw aw ôskinîkiw, okimâw.
sentences.text: kayâs pêyak okimâw nîso okimâwak oskinîkiwak pêyak owîkimâkana miyosiyiwa wiya mîna miyosiw awa oskinîkiw okimâw
sentences.english: Of old there was a chief, there were two chiefs, and one had a beautiful wife, and he, too, a young man, was handsome, that chief.

sentences.original: êkwah owîkimâkanah têhtapiwak ê-sipwêhtêcik, ayâhciyiniwah êh-ntonawâcik, ê-wîh-kakwê-kimotamawât otêmiyiwa, ahpôh ta-nipahât wâpamât;
sentences.text: êkwa owîkimâkana têhtapiwak ê-sipwêhtêcik ayahciyiniwa ê-nitonawâcik ê-wî-kakwê-kimotamawât otêmiyiwa ahpô ta-nipahât wâpamât
sentences.english: He and his wife rode away from camp to look for Blackfoot, as he meant to steal their horses, or to kill them, if he saw them;
such was his intention as they set out.
At night they set out, he and his wife alone.
Dawn came and they were still riding along.
They went on that whole day, until night fell.
They camped and slept.
In the morning they went on.
Toward noon he saw some buffalos.
He pursued them and killed one.
They stayed in that place, preparing the carcass for their meal.
They stayed there quite a while.

sentences.original: êh-kîsi-mîcisocik, osîhtâw aw îskwêw ê-wîh-nîmâcik kâhkêwakwah.
sentences.text: ê-kîsi-mîcisocik osîhtâw awa iskwêw ê-wî-nîmâcik kâhkêwakwa
sentences.english: After they had eaten, the woman made dried meat to carry along.
Night came upon them there.
In the morning they went on.
All that day, too, they kept going.
When night came, they kept on till dawn.

sentences.original: piyis ê-spi-kîsikâyik, êkoyikohk cîk êkwah ayâwak itah êy-ihtatêyimâcik iyahciyiniwah.
sentences.text: piyis ê-ispi-kîsikâyik êkoyikohk cîki êkwa ayâwak ita ê-ihtatêyimâcik ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: When it was full daylight, they had got close to where they thought the Blackfoot to be.
This was the name of the people they were seeking out: Snakes, was their name.
They advanced always behind knolls, afraid that the enemy might see them.

sentences.original: sîpiy itah ê-pimihtiniyik, êkotah tahkih pimohtêw êh-kâsot, âskaw ê-sâkêwêt, ê-wîh-kakwêh-wâpahtahk kêkway.
sentences.text: sîpiy ita ê-pimihtiniyik êkota tahki pimohtêw ê-kâsot âskaw ê-sâkêwêt ê-wî-kakwê-wâpahtahk kêkway
sentences.english: Where a river flowed by, there he went along; concealing himself, but coming forth every now and then, to see what could be seen.

sentences.original: tahki êkosi tôtam; piyis mîna tipiskâyiw.
sentences.text: tahki êkosi tôtam piyis mîna tipiskâyiw
sentences.english: He kept doing this, until night came.
He camped there in the thicket.
He slept there until dawn.
When they got up, they ate.
When they had eaten, he made himself ready, washing and painting his face, and combing his hair.
By this time the sun stood high.

sentences.original: pasikôw, ê-sipwêhtêt, owîkimâkanah êh-nakâtât êkotah, ê-wîh-kakwê-wâpamât kâ-pê-ntonawât.
sentences.text: pasikôw ê-sipwêhtêt owîkimâkana ê-nakatât êkota ê-wî-kakwê-wâpamât kâ-pê-nitonawât
sentences.english: He arose and, leaving his wife there, went away to try to see those whom he was seeking out.

sentences.original: êh-mis-ôsêtinâyik, êkotah êh-âmaciwêt, êh-nanâtawâpit, piyisk kîsih-âmaciwêw; pôtih kâ-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhpah ê-mihcêniyikih.
sentences.text: ê-misi-osêtinâyik êkota ê-âmaciwêt ê-nanâtawâpit piyisk kîsi-âmaciwêw pôti kâ-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhpa ê-mihcêniyiki
sentences.english: He climbed a large knoll to look out. When he reached the top, there he beheld a great many tents.
He saw many horses by the camp.

sentences.original: êkosi wâpahtam pîhtêyis pêyak mîkiwâhp êh-misâyik.
sentences.text: êkosi wâpahtam pîhtêyas pêyak mîkiwâhp ê-misâyik
sentences.english: He saw a large tent in the center of the others.
Close by was a small thicket.
Those were the Snakes; those were the ones he sought.
He stayed there.
Until nearly noon he watched them.
At last he came down from the hill and went to where his wife was.

sentences.original: ômisih itêw : niwîkimâkan, ôtah awasâyihk misâw ôtênaw.
sentences.english: This is what he said to her: “My wife, here behind the hill is a large town.
You too shall see the people.
Get yourself ready; wash your face; paint your face; comb your hair.
Who knows if we shall live when we are seen,” he said to her.

sentences.original: awa iskwêw ê-kîsi-nanâpâcihot, pitah mîcisotân, itwêw awa nâpêw.
sentences.text: awa iskwêw ê-kîsi-nânapâcihot itwêw awa nâpêw
sentences.english: When she had made herself ready, “First let us eat,” said the man.
So they ate.

sentences.original: êh-kîsi-mîcisocik, âmaciwêtân, kîstah ta-wâpahtaman ê-mihcêticik kâ-pêh-ntonawâyahkok.
sentences.english: When they had eaten, “Let us mount the hill, so that you too may see how many they are whom we have come to seek.

sentences.original: mâskôc pimâtisiyahkoh, t-âcimoyan, kôhtâwiy t-âcimostawat êsi-wâpahtamanê.
sentences.english: Perhaps, if we live, you will tell the tale, you will tell your father the tale, of what you have seen.”
So they arose and climbed the hill.

sentences.original: itah kâ-kiy-osâpahtahk mîkiwâhpah, êkotah êh-takohtêcik, nama kêkway wâpahtam.
sentences.text: ita kâ-kî-osâpahtahk mîkiwâhpa êkota ê-takohtêcik nama kêkway wâpahtam
sentences.english: When they came to the place from which he had seen the camp, he saw nothing at all.
They had all moved camp and gone away.
Though he looked in every direction, he did not see them.
Then he pointed it out to his wife.

sentences.original: êokôh kâ-sakâk animah, êkotah kâ-kîh-ayâkih mîkiwâhpah, itêw owîkimâkanah.
sentences.english: “Over by that thicket is where the tents stood,” he told her.

sentences.original: êkwah nîhtaciwêwak, otêmiwâwa êh-otinâcik, êkwah ê-têhtapicik, êh-itohtêcik ita kâ-kîh-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhpah.
sentences.text: êkwa nîhtaciwêwak otêmiwâwa ê-otinâcik êkwa ê-têhtapicik ê-itohtêcik ita kâ-kî-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhpa
sentences.english: Then they descended the hill, took their horses, mounted, and went to where he had seen the camp.

sentences.original: tâpwêy otihtamwak itah ê-kîh-wîkiyit ôhih matokahpah.
sentences.text: tâpwê otihtamwak ita ê-kî-wîkiyit ôhi matokahpa
sentences.english: They came to the abandoned camp.
They went along and examined it;

sentences.original: piyisk otihtamwak ômâ kâ-sakâsiyik, êkotah kâ-kîh-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhp êh-misâyik.
sentences.text: piyisk otihtamwak ôma kâ-sakâsiyik êkota kâ-kî-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhp ê-misâyik
sentences.english: at last they came to that thicket, where he had seen the large tent.
As he thus kept looking about, he saw that the sky had clouded.

sentences.original: piyisk ômis îtêw : mâskôt ta-kimiwan, itêw owîkimâkanah.
sentences.english: At last he spoke: “Perhaps it is going to rain,” he said to his wife.
They went into the thicket.
“Let us set up our tent.
We shall be drenched if it rains,” he said to his wife.
So they built it, of leaves.

sentences.original: omis îtwêw awa yskwêw : niwîkimâkan, ôtah matokapihk kêkway nikih-wâpahtên.
sentences.english: Thus spoke the woman: “My husband, there in the camp site I saw something.
Let me go look at it,” she said to her husband.

sentences.original: êhag, itwêw awa nâpêw, â, niwîkimâkan, nanâtawâpi, itêw owîkimâkanah,
sentences.english: “Very well,” said he; “Yes, Wife, go look,” he said to her;
“If you see anything, come back here.”

sentences.original: êkosi sipwêhtêw aw îskwêw. êy-ôtihtahk ôma matokahp, kâ-wâpahtahk, êkotah êh-astêyik, êh-wêwêkinikâtêyik papakiwêyânêkinohk.
sentences.text: êkosi sipwêhtêw awa iskwêw ê-otihtahk ôma matokahp kâ-wâpahtahk êkota ê-astêyik ê-wêwêkinikâtêyik papakiwayânêkinohk
sentences.english: Accordingly the woman went and approached the empty camp, where she had seen something lying wrapped in cloth.
She took it and unwrapped it.

sentences.original: êh-wâ-wâpahtahk, wiyamanah nanâtohk êsinâkosiyit, êkwah ocihcîhk êh-ay-ayêsisimât, tanimâ êh-miyosit! êh-itêyihtahk.
sentences.text: ê-wâ-wâpahtahk oyamana nanâtohk êsinâkosiyit êkwa ocihcîhk ê-ay-ayîsisimât ê-itêyihtahk
sentences.english: When she examined it, it looked like paints of all colors, and she turned it over and over in her hand, thinking, “How beautiful!”

sentences.original: mêkwâc êkosi êh-tôtahk, mêkwâc, kêkway miyâmay, êh-itêyihtahk, êh-itâpit, âsay êkotah kâ-takohtêyit êh-têhtapiyit oskinîkiwah.
sentences.text: mêkwâc êkosi ê-tôtahk mêkwâc ê-itêyihtahk ê-itâpit âsay êkota kâ-takohtêyit ê-têhtapiyit oskinîkiwa
sentences.english: While she was doing this and thinking, “Surely this amounts to something,” when she looked up, there had approached, meanwhile,  a youth on horseback.

sentences.original: mistahê miyosiyiwah ôh ôskinîkiwah, acosisah ê-nîmâskwêyit êkwah câpihcikanis êkwah cîkahikani-pakamâkanis.
sentences.text: mistahi miyosiyiwa ôhi oskinîkiwa acosisa ê-nîmâskwêyit êkwa câpihcikanis êkwa cîkahikani-pakamâkanis
sentences.english: Very handsome was this youth, and he was armed with arrows, a lance, and a tomahawk.

sentences.original: êkwah oskotâkayiw mîkisah kikamoyiwa, êkwah sihkosiwayânah oskotâkayihk, otâsiyihk mînah; mînah otakohp mîkisiwiyiw.
sentences.text: êkwa oskotâkayiyiw mîkisa kikamoyiwa êkwa sihkosiwayâna oskotâkayihk otâsiyihk mîna mîna otakohp mîkisiwiyiw
sentences.english: And beads were on his coat and weasel-skins on his coat and his breeches; and beaded was his robe.

sentences.original: êh-kitotikot, namoya nisitohtawêw; êh-kitôtât, wîstah namoya nisitohtâk.
sentences.text: ê-kitotikot namôya nisitohtawêw ê-kitotât wîsta namôya nisitohtâk
sentences.english: When he spoke to her, she did not understand his speech, and when she spoke to him, he, too, did not understand her.
“What manner of person are you?” he asked her by signs.
“Oh, a woman of another tribe,” she told him by signs.

sentences.original: âh, têhtap ôtah, itik aw îskwêw;
sentences.english: “Now, mount here,” he told her;
“I shall take you home with me,” he gestured to her;
“Close by here is the camp,” he made sign to her;
“You shall not be killed;
my father is the chief.

sentences.original: êwôkô oma êtah ê-kîh-wîkit nôhtâwiy, itinamâk.
sentences.english: This very place is where my father had his camp,” he told her by signs.
“Presently,” she told him by gesture;

sentences.original: ô, ôma kâ-sakâk, êkotah niwîkimâkan ayâw.
sentences.english: “Over in that thicket is my husband.
Him I give to you; kill him.
When you have killed him, I will go with you.

sentences.original: nîsoh misatimwak êkotah ayâwak ê-mihkawikîcik, êkwah awa niwîkimâkan k-ôhtohtêyâhk êh-okimâwit.
sentences.english: Two swift horses are there, and my husband, who is a chief whence we came.
If you slay him, you yourself by that will be a chief,” she told him.
“Very well,” said the youth.
“Thus I shall speak to him,” said the woman.
sentences.footnote: LB:  What she would say was not dictated.

sentences.english: “Go on,” he told her.

sentences.original: ati-sipwêhtêw, ê-sêskisit, owîkimâkanah êh-itât, niwîkimâkan, wiyamanak ês ôkih mistah êh-miyosicik, itêw.
sentences.english: She went from there to the grove and said to her husband, “My husband, it seems that these are beautiful paints,” she told him.

sentences.original: mahtih, itwêw awah nâpêw, êh-nahapit aw îskwêw, êh-wâ-wâpamâyit owîkimâkanah.
sentences.text: itwêw awa nâpêw ê-nahapit awa iskwêw ê-wâ-wâpamâyit owîkimâkana
sentences.english: “Let us see,” said he; and the woman sat down while her husband examined it.

sentences.original: ômisi itêyihtam awa nâpêw : nikah-wâpamâwak ôkih, itêyihtam;
sentences.english: Thus thought the man: “I shall look at these things,” he thought;

sentences.original: mâskôc awa awiyah wâpamêw, itêyimêw owîkimâkanah, tahkih êh-nanâtawâpiyit; kêtâpamâcih tapahciskwêyiwah.
sentences.text: itêyimêw owîkimâkana tahki ê-nanâtawâpiyit kêtâpamâci tapahtiskwêyiyiwa
sentences.english: “Perhaps she has seen someone,” he thought of his wife, for she kept looking out as though she sought some sight and, whenever he watched her, would lower her head.
Suddenly he heard a man approaching.
When he tried to get on his feet, his wife laid her hands on him and tried to distract his attention.
When he jumped aside, the youth was about to strike him with his tomahawk.
He threw his wife before him as a shield, and kept doing so.
The youth could not strike him.
At last the woman became tired.

sentences.original: aw ôskinîkiw oskâtihk pahkisiniyiwah ôh îskwêwah; kawiwêpiskâk.
sentences.text: awa oskinîkiw oskâtihk pahkisiniyiwa ôhi iskwêwa kawiwêpiskâk
sentences.english: She fell against the young man's legs, knocking him over.

sentences.original: êkos âwa nâpêw kwâskwêpayihôw; wâskikaniyihk êkotah tah-tahkiskawêw;
sentences.text: êkosi awa nâpêw kwâskwêpayihôw wâskikaniyihk êkota ta-tahkiskawêw
sentences.english: At that the man jumped, stamping on the other's chest;

sentences.original: piyisk otinam ocîkahikanisiyiw, êwôkô ohci êh-câ-cîkahwêt.
sentences.text: piyisk otinam ocîkahikanisiyiw êwako ohci ê-câ-cîkahwât
sentences.english: at last he got hold of the other's hatchet, and kept striking him with it.
He slew him; he took his scalp.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah ômis îtêw : niwîkimâkan, êh-pêyakot ciy awah ?
sentences.english: Thereupon he spoke to her: “My wife, was this man alone?”
“Yes,” answered she.
“Was this all the equipment he had?”

sentences.original: nama wiya, itwêw aw îskwêw, masinasôw-atimwah êh-têhtapit, sihkosiwayânasâkay kîh-kikasâkêw; mîn êkotôwahk kîh-kikitâsêw.
sentences.english: “No,” she said, “for he rode a brindled horse, and a  weasel-skin coat he wore, and breeches of the like.
Beaded was his  blanket-robe.
And arrows he bore and a lance.”

sentences.original: tânisi mâka êy-itêyihtaman kâ-miciminiyan ? êh-miywêyimat cî ? itêw owîkimâkanah.
sentences.english: “And what was your thought, that you held me? Was it that you loved him?” he asked his wife.
“Yes,” she answered.
“And how did you see him?”

sentences.original: mêkwâc ôkih wiyamanak êh-wâpamakik, êkotah kâ-takohtêt.
sentences.english: “While I was looking at these paints, to that place he came.
'Come, mount my horse,' he said to me;
'I will take you home with me,' he said.
'No,' I said to him,
'Over in yonder grove is my husband,' I told him; 'Two swift horses and my husband, who is a chief whence we came.
I give him to you to slay;
you will be a chief, it you slay him,' I said to him.
When he said, 'Yes,' to me, I came back to this grove,” said the woman.
“So that is it!” said the man;

sentences.original: êkosi mâka oyahpis awa kitêhtapiwin, itwêw awa nâpêw;
sentences.english: “Well then, do you saddle this your mount,” said he;
“Let us flee from here,” he said to her.
Accordingly they saddled their horses.

sentences.original: êh-matâwisicik, êkotah nîpawiyiwa aw oskinîkiw kâ-kîh-têhtapit;
sentences.text: ê-matâwisicik êkota nîpawiyiwa awa oskinîkiw kâ-kî-têhtapit
sentences.english: When they came to the trail, there stood the horse that youth had ridden;
all his clothes were tied there to the saddle.
The man took the horse, and they turned homeward in flight.
[no translation: They rode all that day, until nightfall.]
[no translation:  All night they wouldn't sleep.]
[no translation: Finally it was dawn.]

sentences.original: êko mina kapê-kîsik pimipayiwak; piyis tipiskâw; kapê-tipisk pimipayiwak.
sentences.text: êkwa mîna kapê-kîsik pimipayiwak piyis tipiskâw kapê-tipisk pimipayiwak
sentences.english: They rode all that day, until nightfall, and all night they rode.
Toward dawn they made camp.

sentences.original: êh-nipâcik, êh-wâpaniyik, êkwah ê-waniskâcik, âsay ispi-kîsikâyiw.
sentences.text: ê-nipâcik ê-wâpaniyik êkwa ê-waniskâcik âsay ispi-kîsikâyiw
sentences.english: They slept and the next morning, when they arose, it was already broad daylight.

sentences.original: êkwa êh-kîwêcik, êh-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik, âsay kisiwâk kâh-wîkicik ayowêpiwak, ômah ôstikwâniyiw ê-wîh-osihtât.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-kîwêcik ê-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik âsay kisiwâk kâ-wîkicik âywêpiwak ôma ostikwâniyiw ê-wî-osihtât
sentences.english: Then they made for home, and at noon, close to the camp of their band, they halted, for he meant to prepare the scalp he had taken.
“At nightfall we shall arrive, my wife,” he said to her.
“Yes,” she answered.
The woman dozed from time to time.

sentences.original: iyikohk êh-kîsihtât ôma kâ-kîh-manisahk wastakayiwa ôhi kâ-nipahât, â, niwîkimâkan, waniskâ!
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-kîsihtât ôma kâ-kî-manisahk wêstakayiwa ôhi kâ-nipahât
sentences.english: When he had prepared the scalp he had cut from the one he had slain, “Now, Wife, get up!
I have finished it;
now let us first eat;
when we have eaten we shall go home,” he said to her.
Accordingly, when they had eaten, they set out.
Night overtook them.
They arrived at the camp after their people had gone to sleep.

sentences.original: omanâcimâkanah wîkiyihk êkotah sakahpitêw ôhih kâ-pêsiwât misatimwah.
sentences.text: omanâcimâkana wîkiyihk êkota sakahpitêw ôhi kâ-pêsiwât misatimwa
sentences.english: At his father-in-law's lodge he tied up the horse he brought.

sentences.original: kahkiyaw otayôwinisiyiwa êkotah tahkopitam ôhi kâ-nipahât oskinîkiwah.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw otayiwinisiyiwa êkota tahkopitam ôhi kâ-nipahât oskinîkiwa
sentences.english: To the lodge he tied all the clothes of the young man he had slain.
He hung the scalp round the horse's neck.

sentences.original: êkwah wîstâwah wîkiyihk cimatâw skwâhtêmihk câpihcikanis;
sentences.text: êkwa wîstâwa wîkiyihk cimatâw iskwâhtêmihk câpihcikanis
sentences.english: At his brother-in-law's lodge he set into the ground the lance;
part of the scalp he tied to it.
Then they went to their tent and went to bed.

sentences.original: êkwah kîksêpâ awa kisêyiniw êh-wayawît, kâ-wâpamât ôhi misatimwah êh-pêsiwâyit onahâhkisîma.
sentences.text: êkwa kîkisêpâ awa kisêyiniw ê-wayawît kâ-wâpamât ôhi misatimwa ê-pêsiwâyit onahâhkisîma
sentences.english: Then in the morning, when that old man went out of the lodge, he saw the horse which his son-in-law had brought.
He went back into the tent.

sentences.original: nôtokêsiw, waniskâh! êsa kitânisinaw kâh-takohtêcik, êkosi itêw.
sentences.english: “Wife, get up! Our daughter and her husband have arrived,” he told her.
So the old woman got up and cooked.
The old man went out;
he took those clothes and put them on.

sentences.original: êh-kîsi-postayôwinisêt, têhtapiw ôhih kâ-miyosiyit kâ-pêsiwâyit onahâhkisîmah, êh-at-sipwêhtêt.
sentences.text: ê-kîsi-postayôwinisêt têhtapiw ôhi kâ-miyosiyit kâ-pêsiwâyit onahâhkisîma ê-ati-sipwêhtêt
sentences.english: When he had dressed, he mounted the handsome horse his son-in-law had brought, and set out.
This he cried forth: “Arise! Arise, men!

sentences.original: wâpamik êsihoyân, itwêw, êh-wâsakâmêt ômah ôtênaw.
sentences.english: Behold me, how I am dressed,” he cried, going round the village.

sentences.original: tâpwê tahtoh êh-pêkomât, êh-waniskâyit, êh-kitâpamikot, mistahê miywâsiniyiwa ayôwinisah êh-wâpahtamoht.
sentences.text: tâpwê tahto ê-pêkomât ê-waniskâyit ê-kitâpamikot mistahi miywâsiniyiwa ayiwinisa ê-wâpahtamoht
sentences.english: And truly, as he awoke them with his calls, and they arose and looked at him, very handsome were the garments they beheld on him.

sentences.original: êsah onahâhkisîma têkosiniyit, êkosi itêyihtamwak ayîsiyiniwak.
sentences.english: “It is plain that his son-in-law has arrived,” thought the people.

sentences.original: êkosi kahkiyaw waniskâwak ayîsiyiniwak, êh-miywêyihtahkik êh-takosiniyit otôkimâmiwâwa.
sentences.text: êkosi kahkiyaw waniskâwak ayîsiyiniwak ê-miywêyihtahkik ê-takosiniyit otôkimâmiwâwa
sentences.english: So all the people arose, rejoicing that their chief had arrived.
In due time the old man came to his house.
“Go give food to our daughter,” he told his wife.
So the old woman went to give them food.

sentences.original: êh-kîh-mîcisocik, omis îtwêw ôw okimâw : wîhtamaw kôhtâwiy ta-ntomêw okimâwah, êkosi îtêw ô ôkimâw.
sentences.text: ê-kî-mîcisocik ômisi itwêw awa okimâw êkosi itêw awa okimâw
sentences.english: When they had eaten, thus spoke that chief: “Tell your father to call the chiefs,” he said.
Accordingly she told her father to summon the chieftains.
He summoned them all.
“A chief is my son-in-law; he calls you,” he said to them.
One after another the chieftains entered.
“Now, that you may smoke I have called you.
'How has he fared?' no doubt you are asking yourselves about me in your thought,” he said to them.
“Yes,” they answered.

sentences.original: êkwah âcimôw om ôtê k-êtohtêt k-êsi-wâpahtahk kêkwaya, owîkimâkanah k-êtikot, kâh-miciminikot ê-wîh-nipahiht.
sentences.text: êkwa âcimôw ôma ôtê kâ-itohtêt kâ-isi-wâpahtahk kêkwaya owîkimâkana kâ-itikot kâ-miciminikot ê-wî-nipahiht
sentences.english: Then he told them how he had fared in the place to which he had gone, what his wife had said to him, and how she had held him when he was to be slain.
He told all.
The old man was angry at what his daughter had done.

sentences.original: wayawîw awa kisêyiniw êh-têpwêt, ahahaw, oskinîkitik, iskwêtik, miyawâtamok;
sentences.english: The old man went out of the lodge and called, “Hear, youths, women; rejoice;

sentences.original: nîmihitok, âyimâc êh-pimâtisit ninahâkisîm, êkos îtwêw.
sentences.english: dance, for my son-in-law has lived through great danger,” he called.
Accordingly they gathered and rejoiced and danced.
Then that chief, “Come and look on,” they were told.
Highly arrayed were he and his wife, as they watched the others dance.

sentences.original: kitahtawê aw ôkimâw ohtawakayiw owîkimânah kâh-miciminamowât.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê awa okimâw ohtawakayiw owîkimâkana kâ-miciminamawât
sentences.english: Suddenly that chief seized his wife by one ear.
She began to cry.

sentences.original: kiyâm api! itwêw aw ôkimâw, êh-manisamwât ohtawakayiw, kwêski mînah.
sentences.text: itwêw awa okimâw ê-manisamwât ohtawakayiw kwêski mîna
sentences.english: “Hold still!” said the chief, and cut off her one ear and then the other.
Then she sank to the earth, bleeding to death.

sentences.original: âhci pikoh miyawâtam ô kisêyiniw, otânisah êh-nipahimiht.
sentences.text: âhci piko miyawâtam awa kisêyiniw otânisa ê-nipahimiht
sentences.english: Nevertheless  the old man continued to rejoice, when his daughter had been killed.

sentences.original: êkosi kîwêw aw ôkimâw; ay-apiw wîkihk.
sentences.text: êkosi kîwêw awa okimâw ay-apiw wîkihk
sentences.english: Then that chief went home; he sat in his lodge.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-pôyocik kâh-nîmihitocik, êh-kîwêt awa kisêyiniw, wîkiwâhk êh-pîhtokêt, otânisah pêyak kêyâpic omis îtêw :
sentences.text: êkwa ê-pôyocik kâ-nîmihitocik ê-kîwêt awa kisêyiniw wîkiwâhk ê-pîhtokêt otânisa pêyak kêyâpic ômisi itêw
sentences.english: When they ceased dancing, the old man went home, entered the tent, and to his other daughter spoke as follows:
“Come, dear daughter, arise; go to my son-in-law.

sentences.original: kimis itah kâ-kîh-apit, êkotah nahapih, itêw.
sentences.english: There where your elder sister used to sit, there take your seat,” he said to her.
Accordingly that young woman went there.
She seated herself by that chief.
Later the old man went there.
When he entered, there sat his daughter.
“Now, my daughter, deal lovingly with my son-in-law.

sentences.original: êkwah kiya mîna, kîspin namoya kikitimâkêyimâw ninahâhkisîm, kîst êkosi ka-wâpahtên, anohc kâ-kîsikâk k-êsi-wâpahtahk kimis, êkâh êh-kitimâkêyimât onâpêmah.
sentences.english: For you too, if you do not take loving care of my son-in-law, you too shall fare even so as your elder sister has fared on this day, because she did not deal lovingly with her husband.
You saw how your elder sister was slain.

sentences.original: kitimâkêyimaci ninahâhkisîm, kîstah ka-kitimâkêyimik, itêw awa kisêyiniw otânisah.
sentences.english: If you deal lovingly with my son-in-law, he will give loving care to you,” the old man told his daughter.
That is all.
